title: Will a Russian senior government official or Russian naval vessel visit Nicaragua before 7 November 2021?
preds:
The Moscow times is not reporting any particular meetings between Russia and Nicaragua, although there have co-operation developments in 2020/2021.
Nicaragua opened a foreign consulate in the Crimea where its annexation by Russia is not recognised by western powers.
Russia has made military aid available to Cuba, Venezuela, and Nicaragua to cope with "external threats" amid their tensions with the United States. 
The question is how far will the Kremlin want to challenge the US given its’ Monroe doctrine concerning its declared ‘backyard’.
A high ranking visit by a politician or naval ship may be considered a step too far.
The closing date is due and so is my calibration. https://www.telesurenglish.net/news/Russia-Pledges-Aid-to-Latam-Countries-in-the-Face-of-Threats.-20210624-0023.html  https://www.telesurenglish.net/news/Russia-Ratifies-Support-To-Produce-Sputnik-V-in-Nicaragua-20210719-0007.html  https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2020/11/10/first-foreign-diplomatic-mission-to-open-in-crimea-since-annexation-tass-a72000  https://www.mid.ru/en/foreign_policy/news/-/asset_publisher/cKNonkJE02Bw/content/id/4816379

Nicaragua rulers authoritarian style was recently likened to that of Russia (and that of China, Cuba, Turkey)
https://www.dw.com/en/opinion-nicaraguas-dangerous-slide-towards-authoritarianism/a-57845048 Nicaragua recently sided with Belarus, Russia, Syria in opposing a UN General Assembly vote on urgent action to stop the global AIDS epidemic:
"The text titled "Political Declaration on HIV and AIDS: Ending Inequalities and Getting on Track to End AIDS by 2030" passed by a recorded vote of 165 in favour to 4 against (Belarus, Nicaragua, Russia, Syria), with no abstentions, following Russian attempts to excise contentious provisions through three amendments, all of which failed by recorded vote."
https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/unga-adopt-declaration-pledging-urgent-action-1273347.html

EDIT:
"Nicaragua approves Russia's Sputnik Light single-dose vaccine - wealth fund"
https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/health/1580504-nicaragua-approves-russias-sputnik-light-single-dose-vaccine---wealth-fund "To deepen this new scenario, MRT interviewed Alexander Khokhólikov, 64, a career diplomat who has served as Russian ambassador to Nicaragua since November 2020, concurrent in El Salvador and Honduras. On Wednesday, May 19, Ambassador Khokholikov and President Bukele [El Salvador] held a brief but intense meeting, which President Bukele himself made an effort to publicize.
[...]
MRT: You mentioned vaccines. Tell me about the situation of the distribution of Sputnik V in the Central American countries for which you are the ambassador. A.K.: Nicaragua was the first Central American country to register the vaccine in its territory, and it has already received 70,000 doses. Then 40,000 have arrived in Honduras. Now we are waiting for the issue of entry into El Salvador to be settled. Each of these countries have requested a different quantity: Nicaragua has requested more than 3 million doses; Honduras, a little more than 2 million doses; and El Salvador, 1 million.
[...]
MRT: Does Russia plan to open an embassy in El Salvador in the short or medium term? A.K.: El Salvador has a representative from the Russian Embassy in Nicaragua who works permanently, but to open an embassy it is necessary to first intensify relations. That would be a consequence of the intensification of bilateral cooperation. and relations"
https://marketresearchtelecast.com/russia-does-not-want-to-replace-anyone-at-any-point-in-the-world-we-just-want-to-maintain-good-relations-with-el-salvador/52918/ In this context, a preparatory visit of a Russian senior government official could be a necessary first stop on a visit to El Salvador, for the sake of "intensifying bilateral cooperation" there and ultimately opening an Embassy of the Russian Federation to El Salvador. The embassy of the RF to Nicaragua appears to be some kind of a regional hub to Central America.
Wrong time for a naval vessel from RU to visit Nic.  Sends the wrong message at the wrong time.

Nicaragua is a very small chip in a play right now. With a view of Biden-Putin summit, why take a risk of escalation in what considered the America's backyard? Nicaragua is already solidly in Russia's camp, the elections are foregone conclusion, cooperation is thriving...  Nothing to gain... If Biden-Putin summit is not going to happen, Nicaragua can play as a pawn in the game between two nuclear powers. Until then...

Reducing possibility for this forecasting problem.  The recent visit of Russian Vice Premier Borisov to Cuba to meet with, president Diaz-Canel among others emphasizing that Cuba is Moscow's #1 partner in Latam-Caribe, makes the probability (in the context of Russian statecraft) of a visit to the region this year by another senior Kremlin official highly unlikely.  Link here in Spanish- https://defesa.com.br/vice-premie-russo-cuba-e-nosso-principal-parceiro-e-aliado-na-america-latina/ The possibility- not probability- of a Russian naval vessel "port call" in Nicaragua between now and the end date of this forecasting problem, can not be ruled out, however.

An older article of Aug 2018, which might still be of importance, since it outlines the Russian Federation's general stance towards Nicaragua pretty clearly: "Will Nicaragua Become Russia’s ‘Cuba of the 21st Century?’
[...]
Well-known Cuban-American political scientist and writer Julio M. Shiling has argued that, in Latin America, Vladimir Putin’s Russia will primarily rely on Venezuela, Cuba and Nicaragua, with the last state assuming the most important role. Shiling has noted that Russia’s activities in the region are aimed at undermining local democracies through the use of New Type war or 'asymmetric warfare,' which includes various types of espionage (Laprensa.com, April 15, 2018). In the past decade, Moscow has intensified its penetration of Latin America, and the trend demonstrates that this is not a response to US 'infringement' on Russia’s sphere of influence, but rather is part of a far-reaching strategy. Having lost much of its influence over Cuba since the end of the Cold War, Russia now perceives Nicaragua as its prime regional ally."
https://jamestown.org/program/will-nicaragua-become-russias-cuba-of-the-21st-century/

Visits by senior government officials or naval vessels to Nicaragua, and Latin America in general, are rare especially within the past five years. I doubt the Nicaraguan or Russian governments see a visit ahead of elections as necessary especially since the elections will not be free or fair. Russia's deepening involvement in multiple countries closer to home (Ukraine, Belarus, Syria, Libya, Azerbaijan) is already testing the government's and military's bandwidth further decreasing the likelihood of a visit. Overall, there is not a tremendous need for a visit and with COVID-19 decreasing travel this seems like an unlikely event.

Over the past ten-ish years, there have not many visits to Nicaragua by Senior Russian government officials or Russian naval vessels. With that said, the odds might be up slightly with a new US administration and the Russian government's desire to counter balance its influence.
They better be on vacation. And the vessel better have a Walt Disney flag.

From 2013 to 2018 Nicaragua has received six Russian senior government official visits and two naval vessels visits; 2008 and 2013.  None of these visits took place on an election year thus the probability of a Russian senior government official or Russian naval vessel visit Nicaragua before 7 November 2021 is lower than 50%. 2021 is Presidential elections' year and a high level visit from Russia will not be well received by the big percentage of still undecided voters that care more about Nicaraguan economy than politics.  My prediction is based on the fact that on any election year, Nicaragua has received high level visit with the exception of a municipal election in 2018 but never on a Presidential election year. The visits arrive one or more years after elections.

Going against the crowd. No, I am not sure about this.  Yes, Nicaragua is used as a forepost in Central America by Russia. Hey, it is one of the three (?) countries in the world that officially acknowledges that Crimea is part of Russia! AFAIK even Cuba and Venezuela don't do that, though they voted against the pertinent Ukrainian resolution in the UN. Still, I think the crowd forecast is too high.  May be sorry about it later.

Russian Federation has mantained a close political and economic relationship with the country over the last 14 years, due to the proximity of the current Nicaraguan president Daniel Ortega and the ruling party Frente Sandinista de Liberación Nacional with the aforementioned country. Given the 2021 presidential election outlook, it is reasonable to expect signs of this propinquity, by means of any official visit.
To demonstrate Russian presence and support before the elections

‘It will still be worth it to keep Venezuela, in addition to Argentina, Bolivia, Cuba, and Nicaragua on the list of Moscow’s friends. This is because 2021 will transform Latin America and the Caribbean, with a population of over 650 million people, into one of the biggest and lucrative world markets for the export of the Covid-19 vaccines’. (Moscow Times) Russia has been nurturing Nicaragua as a friend based in the Western Hemisphere (US Backyard). The recent announcement to manufacture the Sputnik V Covid-19 vaccine in Nicaragua is a savvy political move by Russia, given the dire US situation when handling the pandemic.
It is highly probable that there will be a visit by a high-ranking Russian government official to seal the commitment. I will suggest this a more likely scenario that a visit by a warship. https://www.internations.org/nicaragua-expats/russians  https://www.facebook.com/MIDRussia/posts/today-the-republic-of-nicaragua-celebrates-its-independence-daythe-ussr-and-nica/2784672414965515/  https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/01/04/foreign-policy-experts-map-russias-plans-for-2021-a72365
As most of the dealings with Nicaragua are conducted through the military or the ambassador I do not think a head of state or senior Russian government official will visit Nicaragua before Nov.

8. Will a Russian senior government official or Russian naval vessel visit Nicaragua before 7 November 2021?
a. Initial Assessment:  Base Rate: 2 visits/shows of military support from 2007-2020 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicaragua%E2%80%93Russia_relations, https://www.reuters.com/article/us-nicaragua-russia/russian-warships-visit-cold-war-ally-nicaragua-idUSTRE4BD00620081214 ). These both followed major world events, one being the election of president Daniel Ortega and the other being the annexation of Crimea by Russia. 
Nicaragua will hold another election on November 7 this year. However, a Russian visit could affect diplomatic relations with the US, which are of very much importance to Putin. Factors: 	For: 
•	Nicaraguan general election being held on 7 Nov 2021-Putin may want Russian forces/diplomats to be present as a show of support (+10%)
•	Russia may wish to make a diplomatic visit as a show of goodwill as it supplies Nicaragua with the Sputnik vaccine (+15%)
•	With Biden likely providing more support to Ukraine, Russia may want to bolster its military presence in South America in response (+5%) Against:
•	Putin would likely not want to antagonize the Biden administration, which is likely to adopt a “chilly” policy towards Russia (https://www.npr.org/2020/12/21/948736756/putin-and-biden-signal-chilly-relations-to-come), by projecting power into the Western Hemisphere. According to Reuters, Putin always like to be seen as “talking to the US”, and diplomatic channels are likely to be reestablished under Biden. (-20%)
